titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VII. Friday. Received this Morning, under cover from J. A. Smith, Cards from the Earl and Countess of Charlevill, and Miss Tisdale, with a Note of the Countess of Charleville at home, Friday (this day[)], from 8. O’Clock and dated 14 Terrace Piccadilly, Tuesday. We have no acquaintance with these noble persons, and though obliged to them for their politeness, their Cards and note were a melancholy signal to me, of the recommencement of at homes, and harrassing winter parties— I wasted much of the day. Caroline Nicholas dined and spent the Evening with us— Gini came and gave his lesson. I walked to Ealing, Acton, and Gunnersbury. Wrote only twelve lines on rising, and composed 22 during my walk—and 6 in the Evening— In making out the first fair Copy, I came to a passage, where the first draught had left a large chasm to be filled up. It stopped of course my copying; and I began preparing the supplementary matter— Heard the Music of the Ladies.

2. VII: A storm of wind and rain confined me at home until dinner time. I wrote twenty lines, on rising; and eight or ten more while making out the copy of my Epistle; for it encroaches insensibly upon my time. The stream runs low, indeed, and it is more than time to close the work, which is already three or four times too long. I expected it to have run at most to two hundred lines and I have already written more than seven hundred. Wrote a Letter to G. W. Erving.
Received a Letter from Coll. Aspinwall; and a Note from J. A. Smith enclosing a Power of Attorney, from Dominic Forster of Leeds, to Gilbert and John M. Aspinwall of New-York, to receive interest on United States Stock for him. The Power is acknowledged before William Prest, Mayor of Leeds, and is sent to me for a Certificate that he holds that Office— John and Charles came home from School— I dined at the New Inn (Laws’s) with a company of twenty two Gentlemen, chiefly of Ealing and Hanwell, on the Occasion of the Duke of Kent’s Birth-day— Mr Carr, Dr Bond, Dr Nicholas, Mr Milman, Sir George Campbell, brother of Lord Cawdor, an Admiral, and member of Parliament for Carmarthen, Sir William Beechey the Painter, Mr Clifton, Mr Flether, Mr Copland, Mr Westmacott &c were of the Company. After dinner we had the usual Toast of loyalty, with the Cheers, three times three; and a toast in compliment to me, of the United States of America and perpetual harmony between them and Great-Britain; for which I returned thanks— The company were all toasted generally, and most of them individually. About nine O’Clock we retired. All my family had past the Evening at Dr Nicholas’s where I called for them and we immediately returned home.

3. VII: We all attended Church, where Prayers for the twenty-first Sunday after Trinity were read by Mr Carr, and the Sermon was preached by Mr Mayers, one of the Masters at Dr. Nicholas’s School, from 1. Corinthians XI:26. “For as often as ye eat this bread, and drink this cup, ye do shew the Lord’s death till he come”— It was a Communion day, and the Discourse was occasional. Mr Mayers is an indifferent, but not a bad speaker and reader. His Sermon was sensible, earnest and ingenious. written in an easy, unaffected, and not inelegant style, and delivered in an impressive manner; though without enough variety in the inflections of the voice. After Church, I rode with the Ladies round by Osterley Park, and left a Card at Mr. Ellis’s to return the visit he paid me some weeks since with Mr Parish. He has been gone from his house here, a Maid Servant at the house told us; a Month. gone, somewhere to the North. Lady Ann Ellis, his wife is in London— I left the Ladies and walked to the Windsor Turnpike. On rising this morning I had written ten Lines; and in this walk composed four more, with which I finished the first draft of my Epistle— Then to occupy myself during the remainder of my walk reverted to an abortive attempt which I made some weeks ago, to write a few Stanza’s on Temperance— I had then written one Stanza and gave it up—and now while walking added two more— But the subject is balked— I was so impatient to get it off my mind that I was ruminating upon it all the Evening, and finally produced four Stanza’s more— The subject is dismissed.— After dinner I wrote off about sixty lines of the Epistle on the fair Copy, and heard the Ladies play, and sing Handel, Païsiello, Cimarosa, & Mozart. George dined with Mr Moderos, a young Portuguese Gentleman, studying English at Dr: Nicholas’s school.

4. VII: A Stormy day again. The two Miss Bollmann’s came out from London, to attend the Ball at Ealing on the occasion of the Duke of Kent’s Birth-day. Mrs Adams had sent them an invitation— J. A. Smith also came out. He brought me a Note from Earl Bathurst, in reply to mine of 25 October to him. A persevering refusal to allow destitute American Seamen, shipped by the Consul in American Vessels to be excepted from the limitation of the number of Passengers; to one person for every five Tons of the Vessel’s burthen— A flat denial that the Commissioners of the Customs had limited the number to the unoccupied Tonnage; and a promise that the extra duties levied on indirect voyages of American Vessels, and extra-pilotage at Liverpool shall be returned— Smith brought also a Letter from W. Couling at Carmarthen. He had sent out two Letters from G. W. Erving at Madrid, of 30. Septr. and 7. Octr. which I received by the Post, while we were at dinner.— My Answer to Erving’s Letter of 26. Augt. was not despatched— I walked about an hour before dinner, to Brentford. This Morning when I rose, I had written a fair Copy of the Lines on Temperance. While walking and meditating for a subject the thought occurred of writing some Stanza’s upon Justice.— During the walk I prepared two Stanza’s, of ten lines each; in the measure of those on Fortitude.— They came with much difficulty, and I wrote them immediately after my return home. At half past eight my wife, with Ellen Nicholas, and the two Miss Bollmann’s, went to the Ball at the New-Inn; Mr Smith, George and I followed them soon after— There were 162 persons present— The Ball was opened by General Wetherall and Mrs. Adams— There were nothing danced but English Country-dances— There were two sets of dancers each of twenty one or twenty-two Couples. The Ball-room was new, and although so long since finished, that there had been talk of having Balls in it at Easter time, the walls were damp. It was too small for the numbers of the company, and for ventilation had windows only at the two opposite ends. The company was collected from the families of the neighbourhood— Among them was Coll. Stapleton, whom I had met last November at Mr Copland’s, and who went with Mr Bagot to America— He went to Charleston South Carolina, from whence he has been about two Months returned— The heat in the Ball-room was oppressive until the windows at one end of the Hall were opened from the top. But this produced a noxious draft of cold and excessively damp air, to which all the dancers were exposed— My wife danced almost the whole Evening, and before supper was announced, appeared so much fatigued that I was alarmed lest she should be ill and gave her a caution— Supper was served in the rooms below, about one O’Clock— It was just over, and a single toast, the Duke of Kent’s health had been drank, when my wife found herself so unwell that she was obliged to leave the table— Mr Copland led her into the adjoining Card room, and we immediately returned home. Ellen Nicholas and the Miss Bollmann’s went with us. We left Smith and George, who with the rest of the Company returned to the Ball Room, and renewed the dancing till
past four O’Clock— It was after two when we got home. Mrs Adams was so unwell that she just escaped a fainting fit— But being put immediately to bed was immediately much relieved. I left the young Ladies and retired to bed at three— Mr Smith had also brought out a Card of invitation from the Lord Mayor Elect (Wood) and the Sheriffs, to the Dinner at Guildhall next Saturday, being Lord Mayor’s day; with a request to address the Answer to the City Remembrancer at Guildhall. I received a similar invitation last year, but was prevented by illness from attending at the dinner.

5. IX:45. My wife had a very good Night, and found herself quite well this Morning. It was between four and five this Morning, when Smith and George returned from the Ball; and about Noon when we breakfasted. I went to London with J. A. Smith. Stopped at N. 14. Terrace, Piccadilly, and left Cards, for my wife and myself, to return the visits of the Earl and Countess of Charleville and Miss Tisdale. At the Office in Craven Street, I found a Letter from Mr Samuel Billingsley at Harwich, mentioning that he had sent me last Friday, a present of a brace of Pheasants; which were duly received. There were a couple of Black American Sailors, who had applied to Coll. Aspinwall for relief; but he had not thought them entitled to it, because they had lately been in the English Sea-Service. I gave them a Letter to him, recommending them to assistance. I had also written to him to enclose an extract from Earl Bathurst’s Note yesterday received. The paragraph respecting the unoccupied Tonnage. Dr Cook (the Navy-Chaplain) came, and introduced to me Mr Frend, and Mr Aspland, a dissenting Unitarian Clergyman, Minister of the Congregation at Hackney. These Gentlemen had much Conversation with me upon the subject of America; and Mr Aspland gave me two copies of the Monthly Repository of Theology and General Literature for October 1816. He said they contained a Letter from Mr Van der Kemp, with two Letters to him from a person of distinction in the United States, whom I should probably know, though his name is not mentioned. I brought them home with me. The Letters to Van der Kemp are from Mr Jefferson; and contain an outline for a comparison between the doctrines of Jesus, and other established Systems of Morals. Young Rotch also called upon me with written proposals to be transmitted to the American Government, from the inventor of the projectile which he mentioned to me some time since; but in consequence of observations that I made to him he took them back to make some alterations, in them. Zerah Colburn came, from his father to enquire if I could forward to America some of his printed proposals which he now has prepar’d— I promised to send them. Zerah is now at Westminster School; and says he finds it very easy to learn Latin— At five O’Clock the Carriage returned and took me up. About seven I reached home. It was dark— I could not read, though I had taken with me the two Copies of Mr Aspland’s Repository, and the second number of the Magnetiser’s Magazine, which the Editor, Mr Francis Corbaux has sent me, as well as the first— But the time of my ride appeared very short, because I was meditating Stanza’s upon Justice— The Muse is so shy and penurious of her Inspiration upon this subject, that I had only one Stanza complete when I came to my house; with part of another. After dinner I wrote off the one that was entire, and finished the part of my daily task upon the Journal index that I had left incomplete this Morning. The Miss Bollmann’s remained here this day. In the course of the day Caroline Nicholas had written to Mrs Adams that Sarah Carr, the Vicar of Ealing’s daughter, had been seized with extreme illness after the Ball, last Night. She and her father, mother and Sister were all there; and I had left them at the table, when my wife was taken unwell and we came away— Mrs Adams sent to enquire how she was, as soon as she received the Note from Miss Nicholas. The answer was that she was as ill as she possibly could be; and was attended by Sir David Dundas and another Physician— We made this a short Evening, and retired early to bed.

6. VII:15. Immediately after Breakfast, the Miss Bollmann’s left us, and returned to London. Dr: Nicholas sent his Compliments with the information that Miss Sarah Carr died at five O’Clock last Evening. We had invited Mr and Mrs Carr to dine with us this day; and their daughters to spend the Evening— Mr Carr had promised to come to dinner, and Mrs Carr with her daughters in the Evening— Dr Nicholas who was with the family all last Evening, and this Morning again, sent us their excuses. Mrs Copland also wrote to my wife, requesting to be excused, having also taken a Cold at the Ball. The rest of our Company came. Mrs Elmsley, Dr Nicholas, Caroline and Frank, Sir William Beechey, Mr Copland with his Son, Alexander, Messrs. Gini, Milman & Hamilton dined with us. Two Miss Armstrongs, Laura and Charlotte Nicholas, William and Edward Copland, Moderos & E. Fletcher
came after dinner and spent the Evening here— After dinner, my wife, Caroline, Ellen and Charlotte Nicholas, the two Miss Armstrongs and Gini entertained the Company, with music—performances on the Piano, and singing. It was one in the Morning before they had all retired. The party was very agreeable. I had walked to Ealing and Brentford before dinner— My Stanza’s upon Justice proceed slowly. This morning I finished the fourth, which had remained incomplete yesterday, and added the fifth— During my walk I prepared the sixth, and part of the seventh; but had not time to write them, this Evening. Mr Milman had some Conversation with me concerning Lord Byron, and his new Poems that are to be published in a few days, chiefly a third Canto of Childe Harold, which Milman says he has seen, and is superior to anything he has ever written— It begins and ends with his child, about whom Milman thinks he cares just nothing at-all— But Milman who has already an eye to a Bishoprick, has a holy zeal against Byron, who passes both for an infidel and a Jacobin.

7. VIII: A man by the name of Jefferson came here this morning who cuts out flowers, figures and cyphers upon thin brass plates, to paint upon velvets and muslins in water Colours; and initials, Crests and arms, to print upon linen or in books. I was persuaded by his importunities, inconsiderately to give him an order, which I regretted by the time he had left my house. We received this Morning a second Note of Countess Charleville at home, Friday (to-morrow) from 9 O’Clock. The three Miss Nicholases were here. My wife went into London with Caroline and Ellen, and engaged a house in Gloucester Place, Portman Square— To enter the 9th: of December. She also called upon Mrs Bourke, who promised to apologize for us, for not attending at Countess Charleville’s to-morrow Evening. I wrote to S. Billingsley at Harwich, and to W. and J. Brown at Liverpool: and received a Letter from Coll. Aspinwall, shewing his reasons for refusing relief to the two black Sailors I had recommended to him. I walked to Hanwell and Ealing, composed Stanza’s 8 and 9. upon Justice, having finished the 7th. this Morning. The Ladies returned from London about seven. John and Charles came home to dinner, and returned to School. Caroline Nicholas stays here to Night— Evening Music. Weather growing Cold.

8. VII:15. Jefferson sent a man here this Morning with the engraved plates that I had ordered, and he made a second attempt to impose upon me, but this time did not succeed. Micklam the Taylor was here, and this Evening sent us as a present, a brace of Moor fowls from Scotland. There was a sharp frost last Night and all this day was very cold. Much of my time was wasted I scarcely know how. The day was fine; and I walked to Ealing, Acton Gunnersbury and Brentford. In the lane from Gunnersbury down to the Brentford road, I saw a man, decently dressed, lying stretched upon the ground by the side of the Road; his face downward, and apparently asleep or dead— There was in the adjoining field a man trimming the hedge, of whom I enquired whether he knew any thing of this person— He said he had found him lying there; had attempted to raise him up, but could not get him to speak. I asked him if the man was in liquor— He did not know— I requested him to come and repeat the attempt to raise him up. I then spoke to him and he answered— Said he was not in liquor; but had a bad leg, had walked from near Windsor going to Lambeth to try and get into the Hospital, for which he had a Certificate from a physician. He had found himself faint and laid down there. I asked him if he was in want— He said he had eaten nothing for two days. By this time two other persons had come up. I gave him a shilling and advised him to stop at the public house at Turnham Green, and take some nourishment— The number of these wretched Objects that I meet in my daily walks is distressing. Many of them beg— They are often insolent, and sometimes exhibit figures that seem prepared for any thing— It is not a Month since a man was found dead, lying in a field by the side of the road, between Dumouriez’s house and Dr Goodenough’s. Not a day passes but we have beggars come to the house; each with a different hideous tale of Misery— The extremes of opulence and of want are more remarkable and more constantly obvious in this Country than in any other that I ever saw— This evening’s Post brought Letters to 1. October, from my Mother to my wife, and me; with several for George. Caroline Nicholas returned home— The Evening was so cold that I could not write in my room below. I read the first Act of the Tragedy of Bertram, or the Castle of St. Aldobrand; but my wife was very unwell with one of her sick head-aches, and was obliged to retire, early to bed— I wrote this Morning the tenth Stanza of my lines upon Justice, and after my walk the eleventh and twelfth, with which they finish— Thought for another Subject but without success— Copied off about thirty lines for my Epistle.

9. IV:30. Being roused at that hour, for a particular object, I rose immediately for the day, and wrote a couple of hours before daylight; by which means I had finished before Breakfast all the journalizing of the day. Immediately after Breakfast, I went into London. I found at the Office in Craven Street one of the black Seamen whom I had recommended to Coll. Aspinwall— I told him the reasons assigned by the Coll. for refusing him the customary allowance to distressed American Seamen. He said that the reason of his not having gone in the Cartel when the Passage was offered him, was that the notice given him to go was so short, that he had not time to go for his Clothes; which he had since then been obliged to sell. But he
said that those who had gone in the Cartel, had been sold into bondage in South-Carolina, after they arrived, in America; until they should have paid for their passages. This was evidently a tale trumped up, and I told him I could do no more for him. His name is Melvin Prince— This was Lord Mayor’s day. According to the annual custom, he came in procession by water from Blackfriars Bridge to Westminster Hall, where he was formally presented to the Barons of the Exchequer. He returned from Westminster-Hall, by land, through the Streets—a measure which annoyed and alarmed the Ministers so much, that Lord Sidmouth, the Secretary of State for the home department, wrote him a Letter to dissuade him from it; but without success. I waited in Craven Street, until the Procession passed by it in the Strand and then joined in it. The crowd of People throughout the way was as great as the Streets could hold. The horses had been taken out of the Lord Mayor’s and the Lady Mayoress’s Coaches, opposite the Horse-Guards, and they were drawn from thence to Guildhall by the People. The invitation for the dinner had been for four O’Clock. And the Procession arrived there just at that hour; but the Company were assembling until six— None of the Cabinet Ministers were there; nor any of the chief judges of the king’s Courts— But the Puisné judges of the king’s Bench, Common Pleas and Exchequer were almost all there. Sir William Scott the judge of the Admiralty Court was peculiarly polite and attentive to me— No other foreign Minister was there, which made my situation somewhat auward. At first the Company were received in the Council chamber, but soon after passed into the Court of King’s Bench where the Lady Mayoress sat in State, full dressed and hooped to receive them— About six they all repaired to the great Hall, where tables were laid for upwards of one thousand persons, and all, except the Company of the Lord Mayor’s own table were already seated. My card was in a Plate at the Right hand of the Lord Mayor, but after the Members of both Houses of Parliament. This is the rule at the City Feasts, and is the reason why the foreign Ministers scarcely ever attend at them. Sir William Scott several times hinted to me before dinner, that I should have higher precedence, but I was not disposed to dispute about the place assigned to me. I sat next to Mr Bennett (Henry Grey) a member of Parliament for Shrewsbury, and second Son of the Earl of Tancarville His elder brother Lord Ossulston was also present— Also the Earl of Essex, Lord Montford, Sir Samuel Romilly, the Attorney General, Garrow, the Master of the Rolls, Mr William Smith, member from Norwich, Sir Robert Wilson, Mr Curran, Major Cartwright and Mr Reeves— The Duke of Sussex would have attended, but the Queen sent him yesterday a message positively enjoining him, not to go; on account of the death of the king of Wurtemberg, who married the Princess Royal of England. The Lord and Lady Mayoress sat as usual side by side— The Earl of Essex at the Lord Mayor’s right hand, and Sir Robert Wilson at the Lady Mayoress’s left— A part of the procession upon Lord Mayor’s day consists of three persons clad in complete antient armour; one of which is the armour of Edward the Black Prince; from the Tower— These persons are called antient knights; after all the Company were seated they took their places in three Niches in the wall behind the Lord Mayors table; one at each corner and one in the centre, where they stood and sat during the whole dinner— They were Soldiers of the Life guards, and some of the most athletic men that could be selected; but the armour was so oppressive to them that two of them were obliged to have their helmets taken off; and they were saved from fainting only by a succession of glasses of Port wine which were administered to them. After dinner the usual loving Cup was passed round, and then the ordinary toasts. After the range of the Royal family was gone through, the Lord Mayor gave the Earl of Essex and the House of Peers, in return for which the Earl gave the Lord Mayor and the Lady Mayoress— The Lord Mayor after making some question who was the oldest member of the house of Commons (who was said to be Mr W. Smith) said he must settle himself the question, and gave Mr Grey Bennett and the House of Commons. At the same time observing that the City of London was grateful to Mr Bennett, for the very great and important service he had rendered, by the Report to the House of Commons, at the last Session of Parliament, of the Committee of which he was chairman, upon the Police of the Metropolis. There was a flourish of Trumpets from the head of the Hall, answered by one from the bottom (as there had been at the giving of every toast) for Mr Bennett to answer; but he declined; pleading the example of the Earl of Essex, who had answered only by toasting the Lord Mayor, and Lady Mayoress— But the Lord Mayor himself in returning his thanks had made a speech, expressing his gratitude to his fellow Citizens for his re-election. He said he felt a double weight of responsibility arising from this second election; and a double anxiety, not merely that of discharging
the duties of his Office, but that of justifying by extraordinary exertions, the extraordinary Confidence which had been manifested to him— He promised that nothing on his part should be wanting to fulfil the expectations of the Public— He retained all his political opinions; but he should continue to set politics entirely aside in the performance of his duty; without connecting himself with any political party, or turning to the right hand or the left. None of his Majesty’s Ministers had thought fit to honour him with their Company either at this Entertainment, or on the same occasion last year. He knew not what the motives of their absence were; but he found a consolation for it in the high respectability of the Company present. Immediately after Mr Bennett had declined answering, the Lord Mayor gave the American Minister—upon which I returned thanks in very few words; observing that having frequently received the same honour from him before, I could only repeat the same acknowledgments— I would add only one remark; that Gratitude was a sentiment addicted to repetition, as had been most strikingly illustrated by his fellow citizens of London, in the repetition of his name at the late Election. In return for the honour of his toast I begged leave to propose that of “Prosperity to the City of London,” which was drank with three times three— The company was however so large, and the noise in the hall so great, that very few could hear a word of what was said— The Attorney General, Sir William Scott, the Judges, Lord Erskine, the City Members of Parliament (for whom Alderman Atkins answered) the Sheriffs and the Board of Aldermen were toasted. Lord Erskine answered; but though near him I could hear nothing that he said. About nine O’Clock, the Lady Mayoress and other Ladies retired into the Court of King’s Bench, And half an hour afterwards the Lord Mayor and his party followed them— There had been for upwards of an hour, an unceasing stream of Ladies and gentlemen passing round the tables and looking at the Company. The hall was lighted with Gaz— Its principal ornaments are Monuments to the Earl of Chatham; to his Son William Pitt; opposite to each other, and one to Lord Nelson at the bottom of the Hall— Bennett told me that they came very near throwing down the Monument of Pitt a few days ago; and he should not be at all surprized if within a year from this time it should be removed— He said he heartily wished it was thrown down— He also told me that the inscription upon the Monument to Chatham was written by Burke, and was admirable— That of Pitt’s was by Canning, in a very bad taste; and that of Nelson’s by Sheridan, and the worst of all.— I followed the Lord Mayor in to the Court of King’s Bench where there was a very large collection of Ladies. The Ball was opened by a Minuet danced by Col. Camac and Miss Wood, immediately after which I came away— On crossing the Hall to come out Alfred Thorpe stopped me to enquire after my wife. There were yet a large portion of the Company seated at the tables— Sir Robert Wilson passed by as I was standing there, and was greeted by a universal shout of applause— I left the Hall about ten O’Clock, and reached home just at midnight. I was labouring during the whole of both my rides in and out of town, to write some Stanza’s upon Prudence, to complete the Cardinal Virtues; but I effected only one Stanza, and part of a second.

10. VII: There was a light fall of Snow this Morning. The first for the Season.— I attended Church, with George— Prayers for the 22d. Sunday after Trinity, were read by Mr Milman; and he preached the Sermon from Jeremiah XIII:23. [“]Can the Ethiopian change his skin? or the leopard his spots? then may ye also do good, that are accustomed to do evil.” After Church Edward Fletcher, Alexander and William Copland, and Caroline and Charlotte Nicholas paid visits here. I saw the Ladies, but not the young Gentlemen. Walk to Brentford before dinner. George’s Portugueze friend, Mr Maderos dined with us. He is a native of the Azore Islands. The Ladies played on the Piano and sung after dinner— I finished the second Stanza, of my lines upon Prudence; added the third; and part of the fourth— The composition is as tame as the labour is hard.

11. VII: Snow again this Morning— A stormy day and Evening. I wasted in most unprofitable idleness, at least three hours after Breakfast. The consequence was I had no time left for writing before dinner, and was obliged to write two hours in the Evening; and yet did not redeem the time lost— I walked to Ealing and Brentford. Received a Note from J. A. Smith; merely to say that he has no French Passports— I read to the Ladies the first Act of Shakespear’s Love’s Labours Lost, and the second and third Acts of the Tragedy of Bertram or the Castle of St. Aldobrand— Finished the fourth Stanza on Prudence—added the fifth and sixth and half the seventh

12. VII:15. After breakfast, and the Morning’s occupation upon my Journal and Index, I went into London. My wife had engaged to take a house. N. 80. Gloucester Place, Portman Square, and the House Agent, Wilson was to have called on Saturday at my Office in Craven-Street, to make the final arrangements with me, and sign the lease— He came on Saturday, but not until I had left the Office. Mrs Adams therefore wrote to him, desiring him to call again this day; and I went to meet him. I found at the Office, Certificates to shew that William Prest is the Mayor of Leeds— There was an American destitute Sailor, named George Collins, applying for relief— I sent him with a Letter to Coll. Aspinwall— Young Rotch came, with a new draft of the proposals, respecting the invention of a new projectile, which I engaged to forward, at the same time candidly observing that I had no expectation they would be accepted— He said he had told the man so himself.
J. A. Smith enquired whether I could not increase the charge of allowance for Office-Rent, to relieve him from the burthen of paying for his lodgings. I thought it could not be done— The Carriage returned for me shortly before five. Wilson had not called at the Office; and I therefore went to his house in Welbeck Street. He told me, that the Proprietors of the House in Gloucester, Place, which Mrs Adams had engaged to take, were at Ramsgate; and there, had already let the house for two years; of which he had only this Morning received notice— He had already written to Mrs Adams to give her the notice, and also to mention other houses that he had to dispose of— I reached home about seven. After dinner I read to the Ladies one Act of Congreve’s Love for Love, but we found it so dull, that I proceeded no further— I was unwell with my long-standing complaint, and at ten retired to bed. I finished this Morning the seventh, and added the eighth Stanza, of my lines on Prudence— In my rides to and from London, I accomplished with extreme difficulty a Ninth and concluding Stanza: but I had not been able to include in it the whole of the thought that I had intended to express. Another Stanza therefore necessary, which I could not complete.

13. VII: I had a very indifferent Night’s rest, and woke at least three hours before day.— Finished the additional Stanza, to the lines upon Prudence and with it the first draft of my Verses upon the Cardinal Virtues—Temperance, Prudence, Fortitude, and Justice. I called the lines upon Fortitude, an Ode; and those upon Justice might perhaps properly be styled a Hymn— But those upon Temperance and Prudence are merely Stanza’s— The Ode, or Hymn which is only a religious Ode implies a high degree of Poetical inspiration; an impetuosity of sentiment and fire of expression for which my Genius is not suited— When the idea occurred to me of writing verses on the four Cardinal virtues, I intended to address them to my Son George, in the hope that however feeble they might be as Poetry, they would have a good influence, as moral Instruction. In reflecting upon the Subject I immediately perceived that its four divisions should not be treated with the same Style, nor in the same measure. That Justice and Fortitude required the grandeur and sublimity of the greater Ode, while Temperance and Prudence were more adapted to the easy elegance and simplicity of the lesser. I have varied them accordingly; and have only to regret the conviction upon my own mind, that the execution has fallen so infinitely short of my own general conceptions. The Stanza’s upon Prudence, the last written, are the only ones addressed immediately to George. They must all be revised— This subject being dismissed from my mind, I began to think of some lines for Ellen Nicholas’s birth-day, which she has requested of me, and which I have promised her— I prepared before and while I was rising, one Stanza of eight lines, and half of a second, in the anapestic measure; lines of twelve syllables alternately rhyming.— After breakfast, Caroline, Laura, and Charlotte Nicholas, with Miss Armstrong came and paid a visit here— Charlotte made me a Present of a small Sun-dial upon a Pedestal, worked in Paste-board by herself— With the Inscription, “Les dons de l’Amitié, n’offensent jamais.” My wife and Ellen went into London— I wrote Letters to G. Boyd at Washington and W. A. Barron at New-York— Answers which have been some time lingering— Walked through Brentford round by Osterley Park to the Uxbridge Road and returned by the way of Hanwell; two hours and a half. I was composing lines to Charlotte Nicholas, in return for her present, which I wrote immediately after returning home, and copied off to send to her by George, to-morrow Morning. After dinner I copied about fifty lines of the Epistle to my Mother; and read to the Ladies four of Pope’s Moral Epistles. The Night was clear, and we had from our bed chamber windows a full View of Orion.

14. VII:15. George took the lines to Charlotte Nicholas with him, when he went to School this morning. She, and her Sisters Caroline and Laura were here immediately after Breakfast. I received a Letter from J. A. Smith enclosing a certificate from Coll: Aspinwall, the Consul, to a Seaman, named John M’Intosh, a native of the United States, but who has been 11 years in the British naval service, and has a wife and children in England. The Consul certifies that he cannot grant him relief as an American Seaman. But as he then applied for it at my Office, Mr Smith sent the Certificate to me. I sent it back and wrote Smith that under those Circumstances I could not recommend the man to relief as an American Seamen— I sent him also at the same time, the power of Attorney, endorsed with the Certificate that W. Prest is Mayor of Leeds. I answered G. W. Erving’s Letters of 30. September and 7. October. Walked to Ealing, Acton and Gunnersbury— Finished the Lines for Ellen Nicholas’s birth-day, and then was thinking for a subject all the remainder of my walk, but without success. The time was lost. After dinner I
copied about eighty lines of the Epistle to my Mother, and then examined 100 lines of a translation made by George from the third Book of Virgil’s AEneid— Done as an exercise for his instructor Mr Mayers— They are much better than I should have expected. Closed the Evening by reading an Epistle of Pope’s. I have been some days unwell, and this morning took a draught.

15. VII: Mr Hamilton paid us a morning visit. I wrote to the Secretary of State, despatch N. 61. Walk to Hanwell and Ealing. After dinner I copied about 120 lines of the Epistle to my Mother—found a passage which had been left unfinished, and which may give me occupation some days longer— This morning and during my walk I had continued to think for a subject, and had finally settled upon one for which I wrote four lines. It may now rest suspended until the Epistle shall be completed. At the close of the Evening I read to the Ladies two or three of Pope’s short Epistles.

16. VI:45. Received this morning a Letter from Coll. Aspinwall, with a statement of the Circumstances respecting G. Collins the Sailor I had recommended to him. Yesterday Mr Smith had sent out a notification from the Lord Chamberlain’s Office, of a Court Mourning of two Months from Thursday the 14th. instant for the late King of Wurtemberg— After Breakfast we went into London, (my wife, Ellen Nicholas and myself) and looked over several houses in Welbeck and Hinde Streets, none of which pleased me; the house in which we now live is so comfortable, that I despair of finding one in London, even at double the Rent I pay for this, half so convenient— We walked down to Craven Street, and there found two more American Sailors, applying for relief which the Consul had refused them— I gave them a Letter of Recommendation to him. Smith told us that G. Boyd had been with him most of the Morning, and was come out to Ealing. We returned home and found him here. He left Washington the 4th. and New-York the 16th. of October. Arrived the Evening before last at London, and is going to France. His health is precarious and he comes partly for medical advice. Our Sons John and Charles were also at home from school.— I wrote this Morning 12 lines for my epistle; but had no leisure for meditation the rest of the day— There was a meeting of distressed Artisans and others in the City of London yesterday; and a petty riot in the Evening.

17. VII:30. Attended Church alone— Prayers for the 23d. Sunday after Trinity were read and the Sermon preached by Mr Milman from 1. Thessalonians V:18. “In every thing give thanks: for this is the will of God in Christ Jesus concerning you.” The doctrine was in some respects very comprehensive and in others extremely contracted. All Classes of his hearers were exhorted to give thanks Great and Small—Rich and Poor—Prosperous and afflicted; Righteous and Sinners— But the motives for their thanksgiving were not of the universal kind;—but, because they were not savages; because they were not heathens or Mahometans— Because they were not Roman Catholics, of the Greek Church or Presbyterians—but because they belonged to the Church of England, for Religion, and because they were Britons for Government— He did not ask them to give thanks because they dwelt in the Parish of Ealing, and enjoyed the blessing of hearing him preach, but that was the tenour of his argument— It is good in every thing to give thanks; but not like the pharisee; because he was not like other men— I have heard of a preacher who called upon his hearers to adore the wonderful goodness of God, in ordering it so that great Rivers should always flow by the side of great Cities. Shylock thanks God, because Antonio’s Argosies have been cast away. It is well worthy of a Christian to meditate for what he ought to thank God; and it may be doubted whether it should be for anything which he has denied to others without any fault of theirs— It is derogatory to the divine character to thank him for making us his spoiled children—favourites loaded with blessings, which he has denied to others not less deserving than ourselves.— The boys went to the Meeting House on Boston Terrace— The Ladies took a walk with Mr Boyd— I walked an hour before dinner alone— In the Evening the Ladies gave us Musick. I read a Sermon of Bishop Horsley’s, and had much Conversation with Mr Boyd— Smith promised us yesterday, that he would come out to day, but did not. The boys solicited and obtained permission, to stay at home this Night— I wrote 24 lines for my Epistle.

18. VII: Our Sons, John and Charles returned to school this morning; and Mr Boyd returned to London, before Breakfast. Laura and Charlotte Nicholas with one of the Miss Armstrong’s were here. Ellen Nicholas went home with them, but came back this Evening with George. I wrote a Letter to my Mother, and answered several Letters lately received from Coll: Aspinwall. Walk to Gunnersbury & Brentford. Dined tête à tête with my wife— Ellen and George came in immediately after— I copied 100 lines of the Epistle to my Mother, & brought it nearly to a close. Read the second of Bishop Horsley’s Sermons, upon the future coming of Christ— In my walk I prepared eight lines of verses on the subject which I have now undertaken, and wrote them down. But I think I must abandon it. Mr Milman was here.

19. VII. There was this Morning between the hours of 8 and 11. O’Clock, an Eclipse of the Sun of 9 1/2 digits. we had made preparations for observing it— The Sun rose perfectly clear, and there was every appearance that we should see it advantageously. But within ten minutes before the eclipse commenced a cloud formed itself into which the Sun entered, and by which it remained veiled during the whole continuance of the Eclipse, and from which the Sun issued again within ten minutes after the eclipse was over— Ellen Nicholas and George were in my Cabinet to see the phenomenon, but we were all disappointed— There was only one period of two or three minutes when the Sun was sufficiently disengaged from the Clouds, to enable us to perceive that it was eclipsed— After it was
over I went into London, and on the way finished reading the pamphlet entitled the Emigrant’s Guide; a publication intended to dissuade the people of this Country from emigrating to the United States of America; and urging them if they must go to choose in preference the British Provinces in North America. I took at the Stationer Williams’s, the last Numbers of the Edinburgh and Quarterly Reviews. At the Office in Craven Street I found a black Seaman named Robinson, applying for a Letter to the Consul, to obtain Relief; which I gave him. Mr E. Copeland had been at the Office and left there a Letter from my brother to me, dated March 11. 1815. recommending Copeland to me; and mentioning the long missing Letter, as being sent by Copeland at the same time. But Copeland has neither explained why he did not deliver this Letter to me, when he saw me at Paris in May 1815. nor what became of the important Letter from my brother, still missing; nor how the other letters from my family, with which he, Copeland, was charged, were left in a drawer at the New-England Coffee-House, and after the lapse of a year, there accidentally found by a new Master of the house, who sent them to me— Copeland is now going to America. Mr Robert Patterson has also been to the Office. He and his Ladies have been spending several weeks at Mr Coke’s in Norfolk, and at the Earl of Westmorland’s. They are going to Brighton. They propose to come out and pay us a visit— Mr Smith had sent out by the Post a Card of invitation from Mr W. Frend, to dine with him next Saturday; which he answered for me; and a Note from the Board of Trade, signed Thomas Lack, relating to one point of my note to Mr Robinson of 22. May last— As I was preparing to leave the Office, Mr Boyd came in, and I prevailed upon him to come home with me. My wife was unwell and did not dine with us. She came in however after dinner, for the Evening.

20. VII:15. Mr Boyd returned early this Morning to London. I received a Note, of Countess Charleville at home next Friday from 9 O’Clock. and a Letter from T. J. Parker styling himself an Agent, and stating that there is arrived from St. Petersburg [symbols] 1. Box contents unknown [symbols] the Ship Holderness, and offering himself to procure the landing of it from the vessel, and to forward it agreeable to my Orders from His Majesty’s Warehouse— Neither my wife nor I know any thing about this box; nor why it was sent to me. I walked round by Osterly Park. We all dined and spent the Evening at Dr Nicholas’s. Mrs Ball and Miss Matthias, General Wetherall and his brother, Major Fortnam, Mr Copeland, and a young Mr Cox were there at dinner; and Alexander & William Copland in the Evening. There was music after dinner— Dr. Nicholas played on the Clarinett— His daughter on the Piano and sung with my wife— We came home about eleven. In my walk I made an addition of 22 lines for my epistle.

21. VII:30. My wife with Ellen Nicholas and George went to London. John and Charles dined at home. Walk round by Hanwell Ealing and Brentford. Received a Note from Earl Bathurst—calling upon me to take measures for sending home destitute American Seamen— Wrote a Letter to W. Shaler, Consul General at Algiers. After dinner I read cursorily several Articles in the 30th. number of the Quarterly Review— Mrs Ball and Mrs (properly Miss) Mathias left Cards here while my wife was gone. I wrote 34 lines for my epistle and copied nearly 30. bringing it to a close. The lines I am now writing are an addition of topics which I had carelessly passed over in the first draught— But my own work has sunk so much in my own estimation, that I shall probably not send it—at least not at present.

22. VII: The Misses Nicholas were here all the morning. I walked on the road to Windsor about two hours— Began a Note to Earl Bathurst in answer to that received yesterday from him. Received a Letter from J. Maury at Liverpool, with information that he had received and forwarded by the Coach five Packets for me. I read afternoon the Edinburgh Review of Walter Scott’s Edition of Swift’s works— It is an elaborate attempt to degrade the character of Swift as a Man: a politician and a writer. It would be difficult to defend him upon either of the points. I wrote about 40 lines for my Epistle.

23. VII. After finishing my Note in answer to that of Earl Bathurst I went into London, and found at the Office the Packets forwarded from Liverpool by Mr Maury. There were five Packets of despatches from the Department of State. viz. 1. A Letter from John Graham of 5th. October, enclosing copies of sundry papers relating to the fisheries. 2. Letter from Graham of 5. October, with copies of several papers, respecting a number of Revenue Bonds, given to the Collector of the Customs at Passamaquoddy; taken by the British at Eastport, Moose Island in July 1814. and prosecuted in the British Vice-Admiralty Court at Halifax. These Papers are all enclosed with a Letter of 5. October from R. Forrest 3. a Letter of 3. October from J. Graham, enclosing a Packet for L. Harris at St. Petersburg, to be forwarded. 4. National Intelligencers from 17 to 28. September. 5. A Copy of the Laws of the United States 14. Congress 1st. Session.
There was likewise a Letter from Coll. Aspinwall the Consul, respecting the destitute Sailors that I have lately recommended to him— I requested Mr Smith to write a Note on Monday to Mr Hamilton of the foreign Department, asking an order to the Custom-house, for the delivery to me, of the box addressed to me from St. Petersburg, and of the Portrait painted by Van Huffel at Ghent; which Connell, who has just returned brought over with him, but which was taken from him by the Custom-House officers at Dover— At five I went with Smith to N. 14. Bridge Street, Blackfriars, and dined with Mr William Frend. The company consisted of Mr Maseres, Cursitor Baron of the Exchequer; an old Gentleman in his 85th. year. Mr Jones Burdett, a brother of Sir Francis—Mr Frend’s brother. Dr. Cook the Chaplain in the United States Navy. Mr Aspland the Unitarian Minister of Hackney, and Dr Cook, with whom I was first acquainted at Leyden in the year 1781. and whom I have since seen once or twice in the spring of the year 1796. He remembered me from Leyden, but did not appear to recollect our having met at the latter period. This company was remarkable as composed of learned men; but dissenters both in religion and politics, from the Establishments of the Country. Their Conversation was freer than any that I have heard since I have been in England. While we were at dinner there came in a Mr Solomon Bennett, a Jew, and a Native of Poland—an engraver and a literary Man— Author of a pamphlet, entitled the Constancy of Israel, of which he gave me a Copy— Baron Maseres, Mr Frend and Mr Aspland are likewise all authors, as well as Reformers. Frend was a Fellow of a College and a Tutor at Cambridge University; and expelled in 1793 for publishing an heretical pamphlet in 1793— He is now Actuary to the Rock Life Insurance Company and publishes Books upon Mathematics and Astronomy. Dr Cook the Navy Chaplain belonged also to Cambridge University and left it on the same account of heretical infection— I dropp’d Smith at Craven-Street, and reached home about half past twelve at Night— The Ladies had already retired. I found Mr Boyd with George— Going into town this Morning I took with me Lord Selkirk’s pamphlet on the British fur trade in Canada, which I read partly through— Returning; unable to read, for the darkness, I endeavoured utterly without success to pen a Stanza.

24. VII:30. I attended Church with the Ladies. Prayers were read by Mr Wallington. It was the 24th. Sunday after Trinity, and happens this year to be the last before Advent. I remarked that the Collect for the 25th. Sunday was read both times, with the Epistle and Gospel in the Communion Service, for the 24th. Sunday— The notice in the Prayer-Book is that the Collect, Epistle and Gospel of the 25th. Sunday shall always be read on the last Sunday before advent. There was a collection made by a Letter of Licence from the King, for a family named Adams, because their dwelling house has been burnt down— A notice by Mr Milman that the Communion would be administered next Sunday: (which it is the first Sunday of every Month) a Notice read by Atlee the Clerk, that a Court-Baron would be held by the Bishop of London, Lord of the Manor of Ealing, at Hammersmith on Monday the 2d. of December— Another notice for the Inhabitants to meet next Wednesday to make an assessment for the immediate relief of the Poor— The Sermon was preached by Mr Milman, from 2. Peter III.18. “But grow in grace, and in the knowledge of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ. To him be glory both now and for ever. Amen.” Mr Boyd went with George to the dissenting Chapel on the Terrace— I walked an hour before dinner— George dined with Mr Maderos. We had in the Evening Caroline, Laura, Charlotte and Frank Nicholas, Edward Fletcher and Maderos. The Ladies played on the Piano and sung— The day was uncommonly fine, but the weather Cold. A sharp frost last Night. I completed this morning the Stanza, that I had in vain endeavoured to make out last Night. But I find invariably that those verses which come with the greatest difficulty are the most decisively good for Nothing. I likewise added one Stanza more, prepared during my walk.

25. VIII: Mr Boyd returned this Morning to London. My wife and Ellen Nicholas went to town with him and in the Evening to Drury Lane Theatre.— I dined and spent the day and Evening alone. George came home from school about ten this Evening. I walked to Hanwell and Ealing. Wrote to my Mother. Day passed in reading and reflecting upon the papers received from the Department of State. In my walk I prepared two Short eight-lined Stanza’s upon a new subject. Received a Card from Mr and Mrs Carr, of thanks for obliging inquiries.

26. VII:15. The Ladies reached home about one this Morning— Brought me a Letter from Mr Gallatin at Paris, introductory to Count George de Caraman; who comes here as Secretary to the French Embassy. He left it with his Card at the Office in Craven-Street. He was several years a Secretary of the French Legation in the United States, and is very strongly recommended by Mr Gallatin— Also a Letter from W. Davy the Consul at Kingston upon Hull, complaining that the extra-duties upon foreign Vessels, continue to be levied upon American Vessels at that Port, notwithstanding the Commercial Convention of 3. July 1815— The weather prevented me from going into London early, and it was near four O’Clock when I got to the Office at Craven Street.— I directed the Coachman to proceed directly from the stables at five, and overtake me on the way home. I found at the Office, Mr E. Copeland and Mr Connell. Mr Copeland is undecided when he shall embark for the United States. He gave no satisfactory account of the Letters from my family
with which he had been entrusted; one of which, an important one, from my brother, is yet missing. Connell promised to come out and dine with us to morrow— Mr Boyd soon afterwards came in; and then a Mr Feltham with whom Boyd is contracting for various articles to be used in rebuilding the Capitol and President’s house at Washington. Boyd had referred him to me, as a warrant for his authority, which I accordingly attested— There were applications in behalf of several American Sailors, rejected by the Consul, but whom I could only refer back to him— Mr Smith asked my permission to remove the Office into Norfolk Street, to which I consented. I left with him the Letters from R. Jaffray to J. Mowry and from Mowry to the Secretary of State, respecting the suits pending in the Admiralty Court of Appeals, upon the Moose Island Revenue Bonds— Found by the Directory that R. Jaffray, lives 55. Old Broad Street. and requested Smith to call on him to-morrow and ascertain and let me know what the state of the Actions now is— I Left also with Harris the papers from the Department of State to be forwarded to Mr Pinkney or Mr Harris at St Petersburg.— Boyd walked with me from the Office, through Hyde Park. The Carriage overtook us between the Turnpikes, and at 7 we reached Boston-House— We had a game of Cards in the Evening. While riding into Town I finished reading the Earl of Selkirk’s View of the Canadian fur trade—an important pamphlet; which exposes the infamous practices of the North-west Company of Montreal, in a manner which it is to be hoped may be of public utility.

27. VII:30. Mr Boyd returned to London this Morning immediately after Breakfast— He intends going to-morrow for Paris, and to return in about two Months— We had Morning visits from Dr. Bollmann and his two daughters. Gini was here and gave Ellen Nicholas a lesson of singing. Connell came out and dined with us— He brought me a Letter from J. A. Smith, and a Volume of papers relating to the Moose Island Revenue Bond Causes. Smith has seen R. Jaffray, and sent me an extract of a Letter from Jaffray to his Correspondent in Boston, concerning this business— The Causes have not yet come on for trial at the Court of Appeals here— I walked to Hanwell and Ealing— After dinner, my wife was suddenly and violently seized with illness. I sent for Dr Cook, but she was much relieved before he came. Connell left us about eleven— I wrote two Stanzas of verses, prepared in my walk. Received a Note of the Countess of Charleville at home, Friday next.

28. VIII: My wife was quite recovered, but Dr Cooke came and prescribed for her. I wrote despatch 62. to the Secretary of State; and an answer to W. Davy’s Letter concerning the extra duties and charges paid upon American Vessels at the Port of Hull. My walk was to Gunnersbury and Brentford. In the Evening I finished reading the Tragedy of Bertram which was performed last winter at Drury-Lane Theatre with great success, and which with much ranting and bombast has passages and situations of real merit. It is in blank verse; in a style of inflated poetry, which is used indiscriminately by all the characters— I read also the first Epistle of Pope’s Essay on Man— In my walk I prepared one Stanza—

29. VII:15. Received by this morning’s Post, a Letter from A. Gallatin at Paris, and a Packet forwarded by the Brothers Baring and Co. containing an Official Letter from W. Shaler and I. Chauncey, dated 30. October. U.S. Ship Washington, Gibraltar Bay; announcing their appointment as U.S. Commissioners to treat for the renewal of Peace with Algiers—a private Letter from Shaler, dated two days earlier, and Letters to be forwarded to Messrs. Gallatin, Eustis, Pinkney and Russell. Shaler in his private letter is more sangwine, and confident of success than I think is wise. I have reasons for being more distrustful. He appears to think I have not paid sufficient attention to his previous communications. I explained to him in my Letter last week the cause of this apparent remissness.— The weather was this day mild and beautiful— I walked from two to four, and passed through the town of Isleworth, on the Banks of the Thames— I had never been through it before— I wrote Letters to the Secretary of the Treasury and to my brother— In the Evening I read the second, third and fourth Epistles of Pope’s Essay on Man.

30. VII:15. I went to London alone. Took with me the papers relating to the Moose Island revenue bonds; and left them with Mr Smith, requesting him to see the present agents for the Cause now under appeal before the Lords of Appeal, upon one or more of the Bonds— I desired him also to see the Procters and Counsel concerned in the case, to ascertain whether it may be proper for me to interpose by a Ministerial application— I likewise left the paper executed in Columbia County, Pennsylvania by Lewis and Barbara Jäck, and which the Minister from Wurtemberg sent to me to obtain a further authentication upon it.
I desired Smith to give it to Connell; and I wrote to Connell requesting him to procure the necessary additional authentication, and send the paper back to me— I received at the Office a new Prospectus of two French works to be published in London with a notice that the first number of the Chronique de l’Europe would be published to-morrow, and delivered only to Subscribers— Also under a blank cover; a miniature bound volume entitled the Book of Nature; by J. Stewart the traveller— A crazy fellow who has sent me one book before— Also a Hare; a present from Mr Micklam— I left the Office, at half past four— Walked through Hyde Park, was overtaken by the Carriage in Kensington and reached home at seven. Riding into town I read two of Horsley’s Sermons—returning, it was dark and the time was wasted. I brought out the Prior Documents from 1764 to 1775 which I bought some time ago for Mr Plummer—11. Volumes—and Lamberts travels in Canada and the United States in 1806. 1807 and 1808. two Volumes sent me by Mr S. Williams. I found our Sons John and Charles at home from school. We had been invited to spend this Evening at Mrs Elmsley’s but my wife being indisposed sent an excuse and only George went.

Day. I rise between seven and eight, usually after lying one or two hours in bed awake. Not having yet had resolution this Season to rise by candle light. During the first three weeks of this Month, I was musing verses until I rose; but having grown weary and sick of the results of that occupation, I have abandoned it, and now waste the time in idleness. After rising I begin with the index of my Journal, which employs me two full hours. Breakfast between ten and eleven. Read Newspapers and write Journal or Letters until two or three. Walk one or two hours— Write again in my Cabinet from four or five till six. Dine— And spend the Evening, two or three hours, with reading or music. When any of us go in to London we dine an hour Later— I have passed a few Evenings writing in my Cabinet— About eleven is the hour for bed.
